column1: #Text= "_Things which in hungry mortals  '   eyes find favor._"
#Text= President of the Boston Cooking-School Corporation,
#Text= IN GRATEFUL RECOGNITION OF THE OPPORTUNITY
#Text= PRESENTED BY HER FOR CONGENIAL WORK IN A
#Text=Few women know how to cook an egg or boil a potato properly,
#Text= and the making of the perfect loaf of bread has long been assigned a
#Text=By many women cooking is considered, at best, a homely art,--a necessary
#Text= kind of drudgery; and the composition, if not the consumption, of salads
#Text= and chafing-dish productions has been restricted, hitherto, chiefly to
#Text= that half of the race "who cook to please themselves."
#Text= have become anxious to compete with men in any and every walk of life,
#Text= they, too, are desirous of becoming adepts in tossing up an appetizing
#Text= salad or in stirring a creamy rarebit.
#Text= especially if it is to be composed of cooked materials, nor a tempting
#Text= rarebit can be evolved, save by happy accident, without an accurate
#Text= knowledge of the fundamental principles that underlie all cookery.
#Text=In a book of this nature and scope, the philosophy of heat at different
#Text= temperatures, as it is applied in cooking, and the more scientific
#Text= aspects of culinary processes, could not be dwelt upon; but, while we
#Text= have not overlooked the ABC of the art, our special aim has been to
#Text= present our topics in such a simple and pleasing form that she who
#Text=attempts the composition of the dishes described herein will not be
#Text= satisfied until she has gained a deeper insight into the conditions
#Text= necessary for success in the pursuit of these as well as other
#Text= fascinating branches of the culinary art.
#Text=Care has been exercised to meet the actual needs of those who wish to
#Text= cultivate a taste for light, wholesome dishes, or to cater to the
#Text= vagaries of the most capricious appetites.
#Text=There is nothing new under the sun, so no claim is made to absolute
#Text=In this and all similar works, the matter of
#Text= necessity must consist, in the main, of old material in a new dress.
#Text=Though the introduction to Part III. was originally written for this
#Text= book, the substance of it was published in the December-January
#Text= time, also, a few of the recipes, with minor changes, have appeared in
#Text=Illustrations by means of half-tones produced from photographs of actual
#Text=dishes were first brought out, we think, by The Century Company; in this
#Text= line, however, both in the number and in the variety of the dishes
#Text= prepared, the author may justly claim to have done more than any other
#Text=The illustrations on these pages were prepared
#Text= expressly for this work, and the dishes and the photographs of the same
#Text= were executed under our own hand and eye.
#Text= eye and acceptable to the taste await those who try the confections
#Text= described in this book is the sincere wish of the author.

#Text= Our taste for salads--and in their simplest form who is not fond of
#Text=--is an inheritance from classic times and Eastern lands.
#Text= hot climates of the Orient, cucumbers and melons were classed among
#Text= earth  '  s choicest productions; and a resort ever grateful in the heat of
#Text=the day was "a lodge in a garden of cucumbers."
#Text=At the Passover the Hebrews ate lettuce, camomile, dandelion and
#Text= mint,--the "bitter herbs" of the Paschal feast,--combined with oil and
#Text=Of the Greeks, the rich were fond of the lettuces of Smyrna,
#Text= which appeared on their tables at the close of the repast.
#Text= respect the Romans, at first, imitated the Greeks, but later came to
#Text= serve lettuce with eggs as a first course and to excite the appetite.
#Text=The ancient physicians valued lettuce for its narcotic virtue, and, on
#Text= account of this property, Galen, the celebrated Greek physician, called
#Text= it "the philosopher  '  s or wise man  '  s herb."
#Text=The older historians make frequent mention of salad plants and salads.
#Text=In the biblical narrative Moses wrote: "And the children of Israel wept
#Text= again and said, We remember the fish which we did eat in Egypt freely;
#Text= the cucumbers, and the melons, and the leeks, and the onions, and the
#Text=In his second Eclogue, Virgil represents a rustic maid, Thestylis,
#Text= preparing for the reapers a salad called _moretum_.
#Text=poem bearing this title, in which he describes the composition and
#Text=A modern authority says, "Salads refresh without exciting and make
#Text=Whether this be strictly true or not may be an open
#Text= question, but certainly in the assertion a grain of truth is visible;
#Text= for it is a well-known fact that "salad plants are better tonics and
#Text= proverb: "Eat onions in May, and all the year after physicians may
#Text=Vegetables, fish and meats, "left over,"--all may be transformed, by
#Text= artistic treatment, into salads delectable to the eye and taste.

#Text= been cooked; then drain carefully before adding the oil and other
#Text=Of uncooked vegetables, cabbage lettuce--called long ago by the Greek
#Text= Aromatic vinegars, a few drops of which, used occasionally, lend
#Text= piquancy and variety to an every-day salad, can be purchased at
#Text= high-class provision stores; but the true salad-maker is an artist, and
#Text= prefers to compound her own colors (_i.e._, vinegars); therefore we have
#Text= given several recipes for the same, which may be easily modified to suit
#Text=Indeed, the dressing of a salad, though in the early days of the century
#Text= considered a special art,--an art that rendered it possible for at least
#Text= one noted Royalist refugee to amass a considerable fortune,--is
#Text= entirely a matter of individual taste, or, more properly speaking, of
#Text=On this account, particularly for a French dressing, no set
#Text=By experience and judgment one must decide upon the
#Text= proportions of the different ingredients, or, more specifically, upon
#Text= the proportions of the oil and acid to be used.
#Text= oil are used to one of vinegar.
#Text=Four spoonfuls of oil to two, three or
#Text= four of vinegar may be the proportion preferred by others, and the
#Text= quantity may vary for different salads.
#Text=Though in many of the recipes explicit quantities of oil, vinegar and
#Text= condiments are given, it is with the understanding that these quantities
#Text= are indicated simply as an approximate rule; sometimes less and
#Text= sometimes more will be required, according to the tendency of the
#Text= article dressed to absorb oil and acid, or the taste of the salad
#Text= The dressings in most common use are the French and the mayonnaise.
#Text= French dressing is used for green vegetables, for fruit and nuts, and to
#Text= marinate cooked vegetables, or the meat or fish for a meat or fish
#Text=Mayonnaise dressing is used for meat, fish, some varieties of
#Text= fruit, as banana, apple and pineapple, and for some vegetables, as
#Text= mayonnaise, after standing an hour or more in a marinade,--_i.e._,
#Text= French dressing,--should be carefully drained, as, by the pickling
#Text= process, liquid will drain out into the bottom of the vessel and, mixing
#Text= with the mayonnaise, will liquefy the same.
#Text= In the arrangement of salads there may be great display of taste and
#Text=By a judicious selection from materials that may be kept
#Text= constantly in store, and with one or two window boxes, in which herbs
#Text= are growing, any one, with a modicum of inventive skill, can so change
#Text= and modify the appearance and flavor of her salads that she may seem
#Text= always to present a new one.
#Text= Mayonnaise dressing is composed largely of olive oil.
#Text= yolk of egg is used as a foundation.
#Text= condiments, is slightly acidulated with vinegar and lemon juice, one or
#Text= both, and the whole is made very light and thick by beating.
#Text= forms a very handsome dressing, and it is much enjoyed by those who are
#Text= Pure olive oil is almost entirely without flavor, and a taste for it can
#Text= be readily acquired; and, when we consider that it contains all the
#Text= really desirable qualities of the once-famous cod-liver oil, except the
#Text= phosphates, and that these may be supplied in the other materials of the
#Text= salad, it would seem wise to cultivate a taste for so wholesome an
#Text=By the addition of cream, in the proportion of a cup of whipped
#Text= cream to a pint of dressing, those to whom oil has not become agreeable
#Text= can so modify its "tone" that they too will enjoy the mayonnaise
#Text= For the French and mayonnaise dressings--particularly for the latter--we
#Text= sometimes substitute a _boiled_ and sometimes a _cream_ dressing.
#Text= first, butter, or cream, is substituted for oil, and the materials are
#Text=In the latter, as the name implies, cream is the
#Text= basis, and this may be either sweet or sour.
#Text= (1) The green vegetables should be served fresh and crisp
#Text=(2) Meat and fish should be well marinated and cold

#Text==When to Serve Salads with French or Mayonnaise Dressing.=

#Text=The idea that this might be the utensil
#Text= referred to is strengthened by the fact that many chafing-dishes have
#Text= been found in the ruins of Pompeii.
#Text=Evidently, olive oil was the fuel used in these
#Text=Coming down to more modern times, Madame de Stal had a dish of very
#Text= unique pattern, and, when driven by the command of Napoleon from her
#Text= beloved Paris, she carried her chafing-dish with her into exile as one
#Text= of her most cherished household gods.
#Text= favored few, who have full purses, are found sets of little silver
#Text= doylie-covered plate, and a bird or rarebit may be served in them as a
#Text= course at dinner, one to each guest.
#Text=The cooking is not done in these
#Text= dishes, and they are not furnished with lamps; in them the food, while
#Text= it is being eaten, is simply kept hot by means of a tiny pan filled with
#Text="With all Appliances and Means to boot."]
#Text=In reality, the modern chafing-dish is a species of _bain marie_, or
#Text= double boiler, with a lamp so arranged that cooking can be done
#Text=blazer, or the pan in which the cooking is done; this is provided with a
#Text=The _second_ is the hot-water pan, which corresponds to the
#Text= lower part of the double boiler; this should be provided with handles,
#Text= and is a very inconvenient dish without them.
#Text= upon which the hot-water pan rests, and in which the spirit-lamp is set.
#Text=The _last_, but by no means least, part is the lamp; this is provided
#Text= with a cotton or an asbestos wick.
#Text=When the lamp has a cotton wick, the
#Text= flame is regulated by turning the wick up or down, as in an ordinary
#Text=At present this style of lamp is found only in the more expensive
#Text= grades of dishes,--silver-plated, and costing from $15 upwards.
#Text= asbestos is used as the wick, the lamp is filled with this porous stone,
#Text= which is to be saturated with alcohol immediately before using, and the
#Text= top is covered with a wire netting.
#Text=The flame is regulated by means of
#Text= metal slides, which open and shut over the netting, thus cutting off or
#Text= letting on the flame, as it is desired.
#Text= With all appliances and means to boot.
#Text=The chafing-dish should always rest upon a tray, as a very slight
#Text= draught of air, or the expansion of the alcohol when heated, will
#Text= sometimes cause the flame to flare out and downward, and thus an
#Text= unprotected tablecloth might be set on fire.
#Text=Often a cutlet dish is considered a necessary part of a chafing-dish
#Text= outfit; but as one of the chief merits of the chafing-dish consists in
#Text= the possibility of serving a repast the instant it is cooked, there
#Text= would seem to be a want of propriety in removing the cooked article to a
#Text= platter and garnishing the dish before serving.
#Text=A polished wooden spoon, with long handle and small bowl, is a most
#Text= convenient utensil to use while cooking the dainty; but the regulation
#Text= chafing-dish spoon is needed when serving the same.
#Text= broad bowl of silver or aluminum, with rounded end, and a long ebony
#Text=The filler is a most convenient article for use, when the lamp needs
#Text=replenishing with alcohol, but in its absence the alcohol may be turned
#Text= into a small pitcher and from that into the lamp.
#Text= size holds about five tablespoonfuls of alcohol, and this quantity will
#Text= supply heat for at least half an hour.

#Text= done at the table, as for a rarebit, the recipe takes on an additional
#Text= flavor, according to the deftness with which it is done.
#Text=Let, then, everything be ready and at hand, before the guests or family

#Text=Bear in mind that the hot-water pan is to be used in all cases where the
#Text= double boiler would be used, if the cooking were to be done upon the
#Text=For instance, where the recipe calls for milk or cream, except in

#Text= always to place the blazer in the bath before eggs are added to any
#Text=Indeed, the hot-water pan is the one feature of the
#Text= chafing-dish which it is most important to notice; for on the proper use
#Text= of the hot-water pan the value of the chafing-dish as an exponent of
#Text= principles upon which the use of this rests has gained no small insight
#Text= into the secret of all cookery, be it scientific, economic or hygienic;
#Text= for a knowledge of the effect of heat at different temperatures, applied
#Text= to food, is the very foundation-stone upon which all cookery rests.
#Text=Although the chafing-dish is especially adapted to the needs of the
#Text= bachelor, man or maid, its use should not be relegated entirely to the
#Text=In the sick-room, at the luncheon-table, on
#Text= Sunday night, it is most serviceable and wellnigh indispensable; it
#Text= always suggests hearty welcome and good cheer.
#Text=While it is out of place, at any ceremonial meal, as a means of cooking,
#Text= even on such occasions a lobster Newburgh or other dish that needs be
#Text= served piping hot to be eaten at its best may be brought on in
#Text=These are supplied with hot-water pans and
#Text=At a chafing-dish supper each guest can prepare his own rarebit.
#Text=Any operation in cooking that can be performed on the kitchen range may
#Text= be successfully carried out on the chafing-dish, provided one be skilled
#Text=But as the dining-room is usually chosen as the site in
#Text= which to test its possibilities, here it were well to confine one  '  s
#Text= efforts to such dishes as will not give rise to too much disorder.
#Text=Sauting and frying it were better to reserve for the range and a
